title: Reflection on Using GenAI
text:
For this assessment, I primarily utilized Google Gemini to assist in the development of my Quarto website. As this was my first time using Quarto, GenAI served as an on-demand tutor to bridge the gap between my existing coding knowledge and this new framework.


I used Gemini to explain the specific file structures of Quarto (such as the role of _quarto.yml) and to troubleshoot specific errors.

Accelerated Learning: Instead of spending hours reading through documentation to find basic setup instructions, I could ask specific questions like ‚ÄúHow do I change the output directory?‚Äù and get immediate, actionable answers.
Debugging: When I encountered the issue where my Git tab was missing (due to being in the temporary project), Gemini helped me identify that I was working in the wrong directory and guided me to the correct workflow.
Code Formatting: It assisted in generating the correct YAML indentation for the navigation bar, which is often a source of syntax errors.











Aspect
Description




Benefits
Speed. The biggest advantage was the reduction in setup time. It allowed me to focus on the content (my projects and visualization) rather than getting stuck on configuration details.


Challenges
Context Awareness. Sometimes the AI would provide generic advice that didn‚Äôt match the specific constraints of the assignment (e.g., specific folder names), requiring me to double-check its suggestions against the lab manual.






Reflecting on this, I see GenAI not just as a coding assistant, but as a productivity multiplier. In my future Fintech career, I plan to use similar tools to: 1. Rapid Prototyping: Quickly spinning up dashboards for financial data visualization. 2. Documentation: helping to comment and document complex Python scripts used for stock analysis.

title: reflection
text: For this assessment, I used GenAI tools such as Gemini to help me explain areas of Quarto that I was unfamiliar with. This significantly helped to speed up the process of setting up my first website using Quarto and helped me to understand the structure of Quarto files better.

title: Projects
text:
As part of a team project, I developed a Python-based security tool designed to detect and classify phishing attempts. The system analyzes email headers, body content, and URLs to assign a Risk Score, classifying emails as Safe, Suspicious, or Phishing.
This project focuses on feature engineering and heuristic analysis to identify social engineering attacks that bypass traditional filters.




The system utilizes a multi-layered approach to analyze threats:



Whitelist Validation: Instant cross-check against a predefined list of trusted domains.
Levenshtein Edit Distance: Calculates string distance to detect ‚Äútyposquatting‚Äù (e.g., g0ogle.com vs google.com).
Fuzzy Matching: Flags sender names that visually mimic trusted brands using fuzzy string similarity.
Spoofing Detection: Identifies display names that suspiciously resemble email addresses.





Keyword Risk Scoring: Scans for urgency triggers (e.g., ‚ÄúVerify‚Äù, ‚ÄúUrgent‚Äù) with weighted scoring based on position (Subject line vs.¬†Body).
HTML Forensics: Detects risky HTML tags, embedded scripts, and hidden forms often used in credential harvesting.
Character Distribution: Flags obfuscation attempts, such as excessive punctuation or repeated symbols.





Suspicious Link Detection: Identifies mismatched domains (text vs.¬†actual link) and raw IP addresses.
VirusTotal API Integration: Real-time reputation checks for URLs against vendor security databases.






We moved beyond simple detection by implementing a comprehensive data analysis suite:

Confusion Matrix: To visualize True Positives vs.¬†False Positives.
Metrics: calculated Precision, Recall, F1-Score, and Accuracy.
Interactive Charts: Bar charts and data tables to analyze feature correlation.







Category
Tools Used




Language
Python


Data Processing
Pandas, NumPy


Algorithms
Levenshtein Distance, FuzzyWuzzy


APIs
VirusTotal API


Visualisation
Matplotlib, Seaborn






The core of our application is the Final Risk Scoring algorithm. It aggregates weighted scores from all detection modules.

Logic: \[\text{Total Score} = (\text{Keyword Score} \times W_1) + (\text{URL Risk} \times W_2) + (\text{Sender Suspicion} \times W_3)\]

If the Total Score exceeds the threshold, the email is flagged. This logic allows for granular tuning to reduce false positives.

title: Desmond Chung
text:
üöÄ About Me
Hi, I am Desmond Chung, an undergraduate studying Applied Computing in Fintech at the Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT).
I stand at the intersection of Finance and Technology. My passion lies in leveraging code to solve complex financial problems, from automating data analysis to building predictive models for stock market trends.


üõ† Tech Stack
I am currently building my proficiency in:

Languages: Python (Pandas, NumPy), Java, SQL
Web Development: HTML, CSS, Bootstrap
Interests: Quantitative Analysis, Machine Learning (NLP/FinBERT), and Algorithmic Trading.



üéØ Goals
I am actively seeking opportunities to apply my technical skills in a rigorous financial environment, specifically in roles related to software development or financial data analysis.

title: projects
text:
During my time in SIT, I have developed a stock market analysis project using python to track the stock prices using technical indicators.



This is the webpage created using streamlit


The project involved creating a web application using Streamlit that allows users to input stock ticker symbols and view real-time stock prices along with various technical indicators such as Moving Averages, RSI, and MACD. The application fetches data from financial APIs and provides interactive charts for better visualization.



This is the chart created using python data analysis libraries


The project helped me enhance my skills in Python programming, data analysis, and web development. It also provided practical experience in working with financial data and understanding stock market trends.
 To ensure the accuracy of the technical indicators and stock price predictions, I cross-referenced the results with analyses from reputable financial sources such as Wall Street analysts and financial news websites. This validation step was crucial in confirming the reliability of the data presented in the application.
View Code on GitHub

title: Projects
text:
As part of a team project, I developed a Python-based security tool designed to detect and classify phishing attempts. The system analyzes email headers, body content, and URLs to assign a Risk Score, classifying emails as Safe, Suspicious, or Phishing.
This project focuses on feature engineering and heuristic analysis to identify social engineering attacks that bypass traditional filters.




The system utilizes a multi-layered approach to analyze threats:



Whitelist Validation: Instant cross-check against a predefined list of trusted domains.
Levenshtein Edit Distance: Calculates string distance to detect ‚Äútyposquatting‚Äù (e.g., g0ogle.com vs google.com).
Fuzzy Matching: Flags sender names that visually mimic trusted brands using fuzzy string similarity.
Spoofing Detection: Identifies display names that suspiciously resemble email addresses.





Keyword Risk Scoring: Scans for urgency triggers (e.g., ‚ÄúVerify‚Äù, ‚ÄúUrgent‚Äù) with weighted scoring based on position (Subject line vs.¬†Body).
HTML Forensics: Detects risky HTML tags, embedded scripts, and hidden forms often used in credential harvesting.
Character Distribution: Flags obfuscation attempts, such as excessive punctuation or repeated symbols.





Suspicious Link Detection: Identifies mismatched domains (text vs.¬†actual link) and raw IP addresses.
VirusTotal API Integration: Real-time reputation checks for URLs against vendor security databases.






We moved beyond simple detection by implementing a comprehensive data analysis suite:

Confusion Matrix: To visualize True Positives vs.¬†False Positives.
Metrics: calculated Precision, Recall, F1-Score, and Accuracy.
Interactive Charts: Bar charts and data tables to analyze feature correlation.







Category
Tools Used




Language
Python


Data Processing
Pandas, NumPy


Algorithms
Levenshtein Distance, FuzzyWuzzy


APIs
VirusTotal API


Visualisation
Matplotlib, Seaborn






The core of our application is the Final Risk Scoring algorithm. It aggregates weighted scores from all detection modules.

Logic: \[\text{Total Score} = (\text{Keyword Score} \times W_1) + (\text{URL Risk} \times W_2) + (\text{Sender Suspicion} \times W_3)\]

If the Total Score exceeds the threshold, the email is flagged. This logic allows for granular tuning to reduce false positives.
